posts.name: Collin
posts.cooked: The team is trying to program a gripper for this year. It utilizes a single motor with encoder feedback. Are there any resources or a good starting point for some form of closed-loop control for this type of mechanism to provide a consistent force on the game pieces this year?

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: You’ll want to read through this section of the docs.  This will help you understand feedback systems and closed-loop control.  Then its just a matter if “wiring” up your encoder and motor as feedback sensor and output.  The general idea is that you need to know where you are and where you want to be, then configure the controller to know how to get there.

link_counts.title: Control System Basics — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Collin
posts.cooked: Thank you for this. What type of control loop should we be looking at (or how would you go about this problem)? The idea is to apply a constant force to the game pieces using this mechanism. The initial idea was to just have a constant voltage applied in open-loop but we were thinking that might not be the optimal solution. Would position control to be an effective alternative to do this?

posts.name: Sam Mulvey
posts.cooked: Position control until within a range of the target, then apply a constant voltage/percent output?

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Definitely position control.  As far as how to maintain a specific amount of pressure, there are a few approaches to that.  In no particular order, you could…

apply a feed-forward value constantly (PID would have to work harder to open vs close)

apply a feed-forward value dynamically (i.e. when trying to “close” the gripper, set FF to  and position to , else set FF to 0 and position to )

set a position just a bit smaller than technically needed (PID will keep trying to get to the smaller position but be stopped by the object)

The last one is likely easiest to do and can be figured out empirically through trial and error.

posts.name: rod@3711
posts.cooked:
We also have a single motor driven gripper, though not as cool as yours.  Our original prototype did not have an encoder, so we used a simple drive control with open and close buttons.  The close button drives the motor at 80% while the button is held, then reduced to 20% when button release.  The open button drive the motor a 80% and stops when released.  This worked well for cones and cubes.

We later added an encoder, but the drive team liked the original controls, so we gave up on PID positioning type control.
